content: >http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/03/18/Czech.missiles/ The Czech part of the missile defense agreement is not yet a 'done' deal. Yesterday the Czech PM deferred a vote on the agreement for fear his government was going to lose it. If President Obama is on-side, it looks like some 'pump priming' will need to be done to ensure legislative support for the two required votes on the treaty. The Czechs reading Kim Jong Il's book on getting what you want?
reply: >http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/03/18/Czech.missiles/ The Czech part of the missile defense agreement is not yet a 'done' deal. Yesterday the Czech PM deferred a vote on the agreement for fear his government was going to lose it. If President Obama is on-side, it looks like some 'pump priming' will need to be done to ensure legislative support for the two required votes on the treaty. The Czechs reading Kim Jong Il's book on getting what you want?
title: Czechs Get Cold Feet for Missiles

content: quote: http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/03/18/Czech.missiles/ Having a big ol bullseye on one's country leaves a citizenry less receptive to weapons systems that put them at extreme risk. Most people in the Czech Republic are adamantly against it.
reply: Having a big ol bullseye on one's country leaves a citizenry less receptive to weapons systems that put them at extreme risk. Most people in the Czech Republic are adamantly against it.
title: Czechs Get Cold Feet for Missiles

content: This is elementary geo-politics. They are closer to Russia than us. Plus, Russia can cut off their entire natural gas supply with no notice. They saw that we did not react when Russia invaded Georgia, that we could not react, that getting involved in an armed conflict with nuclear-armed Russia over a small (and non-allied) country is pretty much the last thing our military needs to do right now. We would do it, if we had to, but the threshold for action is very very high. Given all of the above, it would behoove the Czech Republic to take it slow. Right now, there's negotiations behind the scenes between the U.S. and Russia on the future of missile defense on the continent. It would be prudent to wait to see how that works out, rather than unnecessarily riling up Russia.

content: The Czech government collapsed yesterday. While unrelated to the missile defense deal, it is now thought that the formation of any new government puts this project further from the possibility of realization. A massive win in an election by the former government would be a 'good' sign. It ain't gonna happen.
